results.title: A World of Festivals
results.creator_credit: Barry Sloane, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description: A series which captures the appeal, colour and cultural tradition of European festivals and their locations. The rituals, forms of behaviour, dress, music, folklore and fun behind each event are explored, so that a fascinating and colourful picture of other societies’ culture and traditions is presented.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Sloane, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions

results.title: Significance tests
results.creator_credit: David Huntley, Jill Singer, Peggy Girshman, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
results.brief_description:
Episode number 20 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
Describes the basic reasoning behind tests of significance. The concept if a null hypothesis is explained, and it is shown how a z-test is carried out when the hypothesis concerns the mean of a normal population with known standard deviation. Hosted by Teresa Amabile.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Huntley, Jill Singer, Peggy Girshman, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP

results.title: Blocking and sampling
results.creator_credit: Jill Singer, Peggy Girshman, American Statistical Association, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
When setting up an experiment one must consider if the subjects differ in any systematic way that may effect the results. Blocking is used when subjects share the same characteristics but when there may be some variability, as in agricultural experiments, such as the example shown, of testing new varieties of strawberries. A census counts everything but obviously has inherent difficulties which are illustrated. Sampling is a way of circumventing these difficulties and some of the problems of true representation are shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jill Singer, Peggy Girshman, American Statistical Association, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP

results.title: Case study
results.creator_credit: Peggy Girshman, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
results.brief_description:
Episode number 26 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
Hosted by Teresa Amabile, this program presents a detailed case study of statistics at work in a real world setting, demonstrating the range and power of concepts and techniques shown in the series. The case study follows the development and use of the drug AZT.

results.title: Correlation
results.creator_credit: Jill Singer, American Statistical Association, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
This program looks at the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables, by interpreting correlations, deriving the correlation co-efficient, and correlation and regression. Examples used are the relationship between twins’ personality and whether they were raised together or apart, and the relationship between baseball home runs and players’ salaries.

results.title: Singlehanders
results.creator_credit: Kent Nason, Shelagh Mackenzie and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Alone on the open sea! Two Canadians, Bob Lush and Mike Birch, took cameras aboard their yachts during the 1980 Observer Singlehanded Transatlantic Race. The result is more than a record of this prestigious international sailing event. The sport of ocean racing becomes the starting point for an epic of challenge and determination.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kent Nason, Shelagh Mackenzie and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Experimental design
results.creator_credit: Jill Singer, Peggy Girshman, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
Theresa M. Amabile introduces this first program on the design and conduct of experiments. She discusses the distinction between observational studies and experiments, the concept of control groups to reduce the risk of confounding results and randomized comparative experiments. Examples used are studies of lobsters and how they communicate, the use of aspirin in reducing the incidence of heart attacks and how the police should deal with cases of domestic violence.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jill Singer, Peggy Girshman, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP

results.creator_credit: Peggy Girshman, American Statistical Association and Chedd-Angier Productions

results.title: Silks and Saddles (1921)
results.brief_description: This film is firmly within the genre of racecourse melodrama. On the prosperous stud farm of Kangarooie, the squatter’s daughter, Bobbie, is torn between rival suitors whilst her weak-willed brother is embroiled with racketeers and a high society vamp. After much complex criminal activity in the stables before the big race the heroine herself rides her horse to victory.
results.description: This film is firmly within the genre of racecourse melodrama. On the prosperous stud farm of Kangarooie, the squatter’s daughter, Bobbie, is torn between rival suitors whilst her weak-willed brother is embroiled with racketeers and a high society vamp. After much complex criminal activity in the stables before the big race the heroine herself rides her horse to victory.

On the prosperous stud farm of Kangarooie, the squatter’s daughter, Bobbie, is torn between rival suitors whilst her weak-willed brother is embroiled with racketeers and a high society vamp. After much complex criminal activity in the stables before the big race the heroine herself rides her horse to victory.

results.title: Comparing two means
results.creator_credit: David Huntley, Stephen Braun, American Statistical Association, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
results.brief_description:
Episode number 22 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
Teresa M. Amabile looks at how to analyse two-sample problems, using a t procedure, to calculate the confidence interval for the difference between two means and a significance test to see whether two populations have two different means. Examples used are a comparison of two job training schemes for welfare recipients, testing the properties of a new foam product against the former one, and the efficacy of coaching for aptitude tests.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Huntley, Stephen Braun, American Statistical Association, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
